Mr and Mrs Jones' house was full of suitcases, packages and packed-up boxes. The two of them were  _  with pencils and paper,2 _ their luggage, when there was a   _  at the door. Mr Jones went to4 _ it and saw a well--dressed middle--aged lady outside. The lady said that she lived in the house5 _ theirs, and that she had come to6 _ them to their new home.
   The Jones invited here in, after7 _ for the state of the house.
   "Oh,8 never mind ," she answered. " Do you know in some parts of this9 _ neighbours , are not all10 _ ? There are some streets where people do not   _  their neighbours ,12 _ their next--door ones.13 _ in this street everybody id friends with14 _ else. We are one big, happy family. I'm15 _ that you will be  _  here."
   The well--dressed lady got a17 _ when she came to visit the house the   _  time, because she found a quite19 _ man and woman in it. Mr and Mrs Jones had not had the20 _ to tell her that they were not the new owners of the house, who were to move in the next day , but the old ones. Who has lived beside her for two years without ever having visited her or even noticing her existence.  .
